Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2008 10:19PM mommy3abm wrote: gcpommom, I too am a teacher.  I was diagnosed in July and resigned my position at the advice of my oncologist.  I really feel that I would have been able to handle it and with careful scheduling might not have missed much work.  I know of several ladies who did fairly well and made it to the classroom almost everyday during their treatment.  I would definitely seek the advice of your oncologist regarding the side effects of the chemo cocktail you will be given as some are worse than others in that respect.  I did pick up a part time teaching position 3 days a week and am subbing the other 2 as soon as chemo was over.  I started rads last week and seem to be handling it pretty well, although I fall over asleep as soon as I get home!  Good luck to you! Stacy
Posts.Title: Any teachers out there? Need advice... gcpommom wellthy

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 01:50PM mommy3abm wrote: OK ladies - jumping over from the Aug. 2008 board for some "experienced" input.  Started rads  x 33 on 12/1.  Rads onco told me not to start Tamoxifen until after rads is finished.  She said it causes some women to burn more than normal.  Anyone else advised to wait until after rads?  I hate not taking it as my er was 99%!  How are those of you on Tamoxifen doing with se's?  I am really worried as I am having monstrous hot flashes already and I am not on it yet!  Also, my bs is in charge of my mammo's too!  I thought that was unusual also!  Any input on the rads and tamox would be helpful!  Happy Holidays to you all!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo May 2008 KristyAnn Nico1012

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2008 11:34AM mommy3abm wrote: Met with geneticist this week.  She said that most states already have laws protecting insured from discrimination based on genetic testing.  GINA takes effect in May of 2009.  The main advice she gave me regarding insurance was to make sure you obtain life insurance before testing.  Life insurance does not work like health insurance.
Posts.Title: BRCA and future insurance? 3boyz2keep 3boyz2keep

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2008 05:01PM mommy3abm wrote: If you are not happy waiting, I would insist on having the lump evaluated sooner.  You are very young and most likely it is nothing, but it is your body and you are entitled to take charge of it if for no other reason than piece of mind.  Breast cancer does not discriminate by age, young or old, so I would do what would make you most comfortable!  Good luck to you!

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2008 10:10AM mommy3abm wrote: I found a lump like you right above my nipple which to me seemed characteristic of a cyst.  Went to my ob/gyn for my annual a few weeks later.  It hadn't gone away after my period.  Or the next.  My ob/gyn said he was convinced it was a cyst or a fatty deposit, but sent me for a mammogram anyways with the words the only thing you have to worry about is paying towards your deductible.  Well, I went for the mammogram and an ultrasound followed by a core needle biopsy and was diagnosed last night with Stage 1.  This isn't to scare you just to push you to get it checked out ASAP.  My ob/gyn is excellent and has been in practice for almost 30 years and is in shock that it was not a cyst.  Follow through until you are satisfied.
